review_title: World class resources for STEM graduate students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros:
As a graduate student, I have easy access to world class resources at ORNL (I have used both the Titan supercomputer and the Spallation Neutron Source).  ORNL is happy to help UT students in any way possible and offers ample research opportunities for those who choose to pursue them.  My experience with UT's ORNL collaboration has been very positive.

While graduate student salaries are generally low everywhere in the US, UT provides a relatively high stipend relative to the local cost of living.  The stipend awarded from UT goes much further in Knoxville than the stipends offered by universities located in larger cities.
cons:
The potential for pursuing personal research ideas and the quality of work/life balance seems to vary a lot depending on the particular advisor that one works with.  I was fortunate in this regard to have an excellent advisor who accommodated my desired work environment and my own research ideas. Other PhD students I am friends with have not been so lucky.  I would advise becoming well acquainted with the faculty in the department and soliciting the opinions of senior graduate students across different research groups before selecting one.

Construction around UT has become rather dreadful in the past year, and the parking situation leaves a lot to be desired.  Also, while UT's stated goal is to become a top 25 research university, I find that the university administration tends to devote far too many resources into the athletic program and peculiar social issues rather than focusing on science and technology.

pros: It is impossible to get terminated as long as you have skills they can't afford on the open market. You generally are ignored by management as long as you step-n-fetch when asked. You can work from home even if you don't have permission. Just show up to meetings if they ever have them. Free tuition for graduate school so you can leave for a better job, though not for things like an MBA or Law school. Still, if you want a masters in electrical engineering for free. It's great.
cons: Pay. It's miserable. People with skills that Silicon Valley would kill for are trapped by a low-pay logic loop (and the fact that UT doesn't drug test so you can smoke marijuana and not worry about Big Corporate policy). Many co-workers are superfluous. One person works. Nine people take credit. Enormous crusty layer of unneeded middle-management making close to 6 figures. I had 4 direct report bosses all of whom hated each other. Many, many, many "distributed decision" apparatuses. There were ad hoc committees to direct steering committees that selected members of study committees that reported to management teams that didn't exist. Also, anybody who doesn't lock down their work machines like Fort Knox gets rooted by IT Security and spied upon.

review_title: Great if you're only interested in benefts or a free education.
pros: Good benefts are one of the major reasons employees stay at the University.  You can also take classes for free if you are an employee.  I am currently working on my Master's degree and will have no student loans due to being an employee.  You accrue sick and annual leave quickly, so you can take time off pretty much as needed.  This can be good and bad depending on the work ethic of your coworkers.
cons: The pay is not good.  If you have a coworker with a poor work ethic, there is very little you can do about it.  It is difficult to fire state workers.  Depending on the department you work in, faculty members can treat the admin staff with very little respect.  I have heard so many complaints from UT employees regarding treatment of staff.  Monetary incentives seem to only be based on longevity and not actual performance.  There is little incentive to go above and beyond as a staff member.  I'm only working here to get my degree, so I don't really care, but I couldn't imagine staying here long term.

review_title: Terrible pay makes it difficult to stay motivated...
job_title: Research Associate I in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Paid holiday time (typical holidays, plus 1 week at Christmas), 2 personal days per month, 1 sick day per month = lots of paid personal time

Casual work environment with minimal supervision.  Dress code is ultra-casual.

Good spot for people who work well alone and require minimal supervision.
cons:
Truly terrible pay.  Of course pay for tenured professors is probably acceptable, salaries for technicians & lab staff (most of which have advanced college degrees) is comical at best.

Very little opportunity for advancement or pay increases.  Salary increases are possible only with blanket univerisity wide raises (so very rare, especially in a volatile economic climate) or with title promotions that must have strong justifications from supervisor.  One could work at this institution many years without any sort of pay increase (no cost of living adjustments available).

pros: Hard-working students and colleagues, friendly staff. You'll be surrounded by well-meaning  people who are trying to do the right thing even though the system is broken.
cons: The service and professional development that we need to do in order to contribute in a meaningful way to the university community are not accounted for in our workload distributions, so lecturers tend to end up either being teaching drones or people who do uncompensated work because they feel a professional obligation.  Interactions between NTTF and "tenure-line" faculty are collegial, but strained because of the pay inequities. We get paid less than public school teachers.

pros: UT has a very good graduate physics department with many good people, especially in Condensed Matter and Nuclear Physics. Many are joint faculty with Oak Ridge National Lab, so for a graduate student there are many open options. Moreover, a Physics grad can collaborate with a faculty in other science/engineering departments as well for a PhD. For example, one of my friend is working with a chemist in polymer physics.
cons:
TA Salary stats with 18-19k and some researchers are great at research but do not keep track of their grants, which ultimately hurts research, grad student gets paid less. So be careful choosing an adviser, make-sure he will have money 3-years down the road of your PhD.
Career advise is not very easily available, and if there is advise, support is hard to find. But I think this is common in all physics departments, especially if you want to go in Industry after PhD.

review_title: Decent place to work as a student, but not much else.
pros: Good job security, its really hard to get fired on campus as those kinds of decisions are made extremely slowly and must go all the way to the top.  Its a nice campus with lots of good restaurants for downtime in the area.
cons: Low pay, working on a student-salary type budget.  Raises are hard to come by as well since its a state university.  Also, decisions are made sometimes by state law... such that no matter what the actual best decision is, it must be made according to law.  (For example: need to hire a software company, you must put out a bid and take whoever matches the bid requirements with the lowest price.)  Its very difficult to actually see changes happen even for horribly inefficient processes because of the slow moving university.  Its hard to feel important because of this also.

pros: Knoxville is a terrific city! The downtown area adjacent to the University has lots of great restaurants and bars. The city is also very family and dog friendly, but simultaneously caters to single people as well.
cons: UTK allocates money very poorly and the legislature continually threatens to shut down diversity programs, funding, etc. With their intrusion into academic life and the subsequent changes that incurs in the organization and funding allocation at the university, it can make navigating services and personnel each year a real challenge. The imposition of politics (every university has this problem!) can also make employees feel uncomfortable on campus or in teaching difficult subjects in the classroom.

pros: The hours vary depending on your supervisor, but they're usually not intensive. As with most academic jobs you're not asked to do much. Your supervisors never held real jobs, so don't ask much from you.
cons: Unless you receive a multi-year package it's very difficult to get your funding renewed. The school's internal rules stipulate that if you're on a one-year funding package you cannot receive new funding until all of the next year's first-year grad students receive funding. I understand why this exists in the case of people with extended funding packages, they don't want people receiving 10-15 years of funding while new students receive nothing. However, for one-year packages this creates a great deal of tension and stress. Even the students that do receive funding renewals must wait interminably.

review_title: Software developer in a small department
job_title: IT Analyst III in Knoxville, TN
pros: Software development in a small university department is like being in a small startup. You get to do a little of everything, often with a lot of latitude. You can make an immediate and visible contribution, and work directly on projects that see immediate use. The team and work environment was just excellent for me. Free college courses for credit is attractive to some. It also lacks the frantic pace of industry - a good work/life balance.
cons: There was no real career development path, at least for me. There is free training, but for a software developer that seemed almost irrelevant. I learned more on the job day-to-day. While I was there, there was so much turnover in upper management that I couldn't keep it straight, and quickly stopped caring about the university outside of my department.

job_title: Director of Career Services in Knoxville, TN
pros: Great support with Student Life Division, excellent professionals to work with, work with top employer brands, great student base and excellent business and engineering colleges.  Knoxville is a great blend of lifestyles and solid middle class.  Could be a more diverse environment but improvements are being made.  Downtown  revitilization is helping make Knoxville a great place for recent grads to start their careers.
cons: State budgets, politics and some leadership turnover.  Lofty goals and objectives will lead to improvements although it remains unlcear if final goals will be reached.   More and more emphasis on private financial support makes success seem overly dependent on the state of the economy.

review_title: GRA review from someone who was an undergrad and is now grad at UT
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Beautiful campus and surrounding area/city, most professors are nice and willing to talk whenever they aren't busy, stipend is okay, there is the perfect amount of hands-on/hands-off attention given to graduate students. As long as a graduate student is making progress and doing okay, all that professors really require are status updates. If a graduate student needs assistance, all he/she needs to do is ask, and professors are willing to accommodate.

Overall excellent experience so far.
cons: The actual overall UT administration can be politically correct at times, but not anywhere near as much as some other places.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
cons:
- Some projects may not be really motivating;
- Professors may not always be great project managers;

pros: Nice campus and adequate classrooms.
cons: The University of Tennessee administration regards lecturers as disposable garbage. Non-tenure track contracts can be terminated at any time without cause. Administrators don't care whether there is a legitimate reason to fire faculty who have no tenure, and they haven't the least concern for the damage they do to non-tenured faculty by destroying a career. Even if a lecturer has a long and outstanding teaching career with this university, his or her contributions and excellent reputation among students will have no impact on the administration's decision to terminate his or her contract. If you are in this powerless position, you also must relinquish your academic freedom and freedom of speech. If you express your thoughts, you risk being fired. All it takes to lose one's job is a student complaint and one department head with a vendetta against the lecturer. Then, you can easily become the object of public scorn.

pros: I love working on a college campus with new technologies and breakthroughs being made every day.  I also love the idea of the regular cycle of change that occurs on campus and the fact that it provides new beginnings all of the time.
cons: There is  a lot of political and governmental red tape to navigate in order to get anything done.  It often handcuffs programs and projects from being able to reach their full potential.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: I was afforded great research opportunities, both in my own research and collaborating with others. I was also able to travel quite a bit to present my research.
cons: Not all students within my department were given the same opportunities to present research and work on other research studies. Also, class selection can be difficult, as few were offered in my field. Compensation was not competitive for the amount of time and effort given, especially when we were not allowed to have another job.

review_title: excellent graduate program in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: research support is available from departmental funds.  the eeb department guarantees 4 years of funding for incoming PhD students, which is standard for good programs.  there is a collaborative research environment where graduate students and young faculty collaborate to get more grants and research awards than you would expect for a state school in the south.  although you are paid minimally, even graduate students can live well in knoxville due to its low cost of living.
cons: you are a graduate student, and are generally overworked and underpaid for the 100 hours you work each week.  you live in knoxville, which can be difficult.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant -- different departments, different experiences
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Personal growth and learning are unlimited if you are motivated.
Smart, interesting people to work with -- many acknowledged experts in their field
Flexible hours and campus atmosphere
Tuition waiver and paid insurance in some cases
cons: Your experience will vary based on where you work and who your professor/supervisor is.  Pay was better in the College of Business Administration. Mentoring and time with supervisors were limited, but "production" expectations were high. Lower pay in the College of Education, Health and Human Sciences, but mentoring and flexibility were better -- good balance between "you are here to complete your program" and "we need to get this out the door."

pros: Work environment is comfortable and reasonably well maintained. Direction guided predominantly through direct supervisor. Expectations of me are well documented and reviewed on a regular basis.
cons: Dealing with loud and obnoxious students on a regular basis gets old. Paying in order to park at work seems backwards to me. Administration can be challenging to deal with when it comes to simple things: having travel requests accepted, renting a room, or taking advantage of departmental assets.

pros: If your lucky enough to find a job on campus where the department is fully staffed, you can finish your degree and the University will pay for your schooling.
cons: The Police Department at the University is very under staffed. They only have three full time dispatchers, one person who is certified but works a different job and is putting that on hold to help out dispatch. The administration doesn't start interviewing when someone resigns. They just keep pushing their employees to work overtime. Some of the people who live a great distance away, actually sleep in empty room in a chair because they only get a few hours sleep before they have to work again. There is absolutely no leadership whatsoever!

review_title: Great overall, but pulled in two directions
pros: The people are great to work with, and mostly excellent benefits. It is a full-time, twelve months a year kind of place, and can be challenging at times and laid-back at other times.
cons: It is a non-profit educational institution of the State of Tennessee and therefore tied to the state budget for raises which do not come every year and do not match rises in the inflation rate.  The 401K matching is currently at $50/month (also set by the State). The Graduate School of Medicine in Knoxville is tied in to the UT Memphis campus which can make paperwork a bit awkward.

job_title: IT Systems Administrator in Knoxville, TN
pros: A very relaxed work environment.  You get to work with creative people (faculty and students) and tackle interesting projects.  So long as people can email, surf the web, and print they will be happy.
cons: Small budgets and inadequate facilities.  This keeps you from using higher-end technology.  Professors are like children, they will try to pull you into their political games.  Never gossip with a professor.  Listen to them rant and rave, but never talk about others to them.

review_title: As a 25+-year employee, they were doing something right -- for awhile. No more.
pros:
Benefits -- great insurance of all types (unless you have a same-same domestic partner, then forget it), lots of holidays, a paid week off in December; liberal annual and sick leave accumulation
Definitely depending on dept.: interesting challenges, ability to do independent work, intellectual stimulating atmosphere; feeling of making a difference
Also depending on dept.: colleagues and coworkers who appreciate each other's accomplishments and work as a team
Finally, also depending on dept.: some managers/directors/deans who care about people. A few, not too many any more.
cons:
All of the above "depends on dept." strengths used to be great reasons to strive to be hired at UT, and to make a career there and stay long-term. Unfortunately, there are a great many changes in the last few years that make this a terrible place to feel valued. Management, from the president and chancellors down to deans, directors, dept. heads, etc. are mostly out for number one, and care very little about individuals. Marketing and development (the former fund-raising) are king. Shallowness is all. Depth and actual follow-through (work completed) are ignored, if not punished. Being "out for number one" is the culture that's cherished. 

Having spent 25+ years working there, plus 2 degree programs, this makes me sad, angry, disheartened, and yes, disgusted. Athletics has always been king, not academics, but this is more than that. This is a fundamental shift in how people are viewed, throughout the university. Who can be the biggest self-promoter? Who can do the least and yet make the biggest splash?

review_title: Impressive University, Campus is a Work in Progress
pros: UT has several excellent programs to be a part in. The University partners with Oak Ridge National Lab and other innovative and impressive projects. Also Knoxville is like a little city that could - these days it's really great!
cons: Campus is undergoing a lot of renovation these days, and it's annoying to get around. Once the renovations are completed it will be worth it (probably?)

job_title: IT Analyst IV in Memphis, TN
pros: You don't need lots of technology skills, just act as positively to users, especially to director. ask around to get codes.
cons: same thing every day. Each developer just sit there to check email, read code, ask team member how to get codes done, especially some people working there for more than 15 years long, they know almost all code done there, you just ask them actively and don't need to write code yourself.

pros: Opportunities to move to different areas within the university.   Great benefits, paid tuition (up to 9 undergraduate hours) and paid holidays.
cons: No flex time or telecommute options readily available system wide.  Reluctant change in some leadership particularly engaging technology into operations.   Compensation could be a bit better in some areas.

review_title: some good, some not so good
pros: Decent benefit package, good work environment (for me, at least)
cons: non-competitive salaries, disconnect between admin and the employees, constant push by the government to outsource and lose a lot of jobs for people who need them the worst.  Overall feeling by the staff that the University cares about dollars WAY more than the people who help generate them.

pros: Great benefits, although costs are rising fast. Generous leave policy. Some departments have autonomy to make things better - most don't. Lots of quality people, some who care about others.
cons: As with most higher ed, do more with less is the mantra, unless you're in athletics or top administration. Real teaching profs are rare, research is not as important as bringing in the almighty grant funds. Pres. DiPietro is Teflon, cunning but clueless. Actual educating of students is a byproduct of the ego-driven con game.

review_title: Competitive salary combined with a manageable work atmosphere at a large university with tons of school spirit.
pros: Faculty and staff at UT have access to a large variety of cultural and sporting events, a massive library, top-notch recreation facilities, and generally friendly co-workers. Insurance and tuition benefits (9 free graduate-level hours per semester) are some of the best I've experienced, and there's a good sense of community and school spirit around campus.
cons: Red tape and administrative policies can provide plenty of roadblocks in day-to-day tasks. Top-level administration needs to be more progressive with LGBT benefits.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Culture is dynamic, team-oriented, family environment
Relentless focus on students
Becoming more diverse
Never alone or stuck in one role too long - unless you want to be
Get here and your career is literally limitless
Research focused institution with a terrific balance of classroom prep, career readiness, and a campus of openness, fairness, and progress
cons: Moves slow. Huge organization. A constant focus on improvement here and it's getting better

pros: Extremely flexible schedule. Get to set your own hours. I never have issues with any of my fellow employees. We all get along great and enjoy our job.
cons: I guess some days can get very boring when there is nothing going on. Not sure if this is a con or not since you could be doing homework during this time but, that is up to you.

pros: Like most GA's my pay was not much but I got tuition and a great education.
cons: The more I work at other universities and engage with other institutions certain things about the climate at UT stand out.   It needs to becomes more positive for faculty and graduate students.  Internal conflict is more common than trying to be better.  Rather than support for new projects or ideas most commonly you hear "you can't do that because.... (insert some bureaucratic reason)"

review_title: It all depends on your department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: Being a graduate student worker is always variable based on your advisor/office/lab situation, but the dynamics of the department you're associated with can totally change your experience as a campus worker. I was in a responsive, student-oriented department for most of my time here. Notably, this department was responsive to its graduate workers' concerns with pay discrepancy between similar workers. Health insurance here is okay for a healthy, young individual, with some neat benefits like included physical therapy sessions. There have also been huge strides made in the last 5-6 years to streamline many of the bureaucratic problems students and administrative workers have faced in the past. Library, IT, and software services are typically very good.
cons: Graduate Research or Teaching Assistants, even those getting tuition wavers, stipends, etc., still have to pay student fees, which can range into the thousands of dollars every year. This can be a huge problem if you're an engineering or distance learning student taking a full load of classes with extra fees. This problem doesn't stop when you're only researching and are taking "dissertation hours", credits that you *can't stop taking* until you graduate. You have to pay to work, and if your department doesn't account for fees in your overall payment, you could be in for an unpleasant surprise at the beginning of the semester. This issue is emblematic of the ever-changing pathologies of UT leadership as a whole, where the experiences of graduate workers (and non-student employees) can differ wildly. Whiplash from the frequent leadership changes and meddling from the state legislature can leave workers in this and other positions feeling insecure and even unsafe, in the case of the Office of Diversity and Inclusion fiasco in 2016. I realize that the State's decisions do not always reflect the competence and desires of UT leadership, but Tennessee's decisions surrounding its flagship university are an important factor for out-of-state applicants to consider.

review_title: Interesting job for a college student
pros:
-Basically get to "audit" classes and learn interesting subjects

cons:

pros: Flexible scheduling, direct deposit pay, tons of independence. You are never asked to tutor a subject with which you are not comfortable and can easily change schedule.
cons: Poor pay and poor computer system. It involves a lot of unnecessary paperwork that isnt super helpful whatsoever. They do not seem to understand that student tutors would flock with the proper hourly wage.

pros: Amazing coworkers, but some are lazy and you can tell that this is their second job and is just a backup. They aren't afraid of getting fired.
cons:
Terrible bosses who go out of there way to throw you under the bus, especially if you are a student worker.  Sometimes you get a good manager but his or her manager will be even worse and will be actively looking for reasons to fire you because they always hire too many people.

Pay is 7-8 dollars if you're doing basic tasks

pros:
Great benefits - easy to build up annual leave and sick time, good medical benefits
   Mostly laid back, some autonomy is possible
Fee waivers for taking classes is a big plus

review_title: I Taught Myself to Do This
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: Being a GRA at UTIA ensures that you're a part of something bigger, which I hope is translating into network opportunities for my future. I've learned a lot from my time here, mostly because I had to teach myself how to research. Such is the lot of a grad student.
cons: Being a GRA can feel lonely, and it can feel like your work is unappreciated. What helped me with that is just trying to take satisfaction out of getting the work done.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: Department has a great biomolecular Engineering concentration, and great computational and experimental resources on campus and at nearby Oak Ridge National Lab.
cons: Placement in industry upon graduation is lower than ideal. Most students end up taking a PostDoc after earning their PhD. Also, semester fees are significant.

pros:
Wide range of clinical programs with good training programs.  Affiliated with several hospital that have excellent academic clinical programs (Top Hospitals by US News and World Report).  
Reasonable benefits package.
cons:
Some inflexibility and lack of efficiency with orientation and credentialing process.
No 401k/403b/457 matching for ACGME positions.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: The experience working as a graduate research assistant is invaluable. It is a training ground for bigger and better things. If you work with a professor you are compatible with, it will be a wonderful experience. Fee waivers, health insurance and other perks are wonderful too.
cons: Often the amount of work required can be open-ended. So it may be hard to balance out everything. However, this position is essentially a paid apprenticeship. This position gives invaluable experience that will lead to full-time work.

review_title: I enjoyed my boss and my lab, and the university is pretty much just like any ole other university
job_title: Research Technician III in Knoxville, TN

cons: UT has a big fascination with the Vols, even though their crappy football team never wins, and they foist it upon everyone else, regardless of the team's performance.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in McMinnville, TN

review_title: Overall I had a good experience at UT until a new administrator arrived on the scene.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Knoxville, TN

cons: The undergrads can be challenging. Throughout higher education, there is pressure to view students as customers who must be served. This works against the interests of the students, who should be challenged more.

pros: It is good benefits, you can take time off with ease. No work pressure. If it doesn't get today then there is always tomorrow attitude.

pros: flexible hours and schedule, convenient for students, not many nights or weekends, great experience, i would recommend working here as a student

pros:
the students at University of TN Knoxville are wonderful
The Smoky Mountains are great - amazing scenery and easily accessible national park is a boon to nature lovers
cons:
In my opinion there are too many unethical and dishonest managers. Clearly, not every administrator is this way, but there are some extraordinarily slimy characters working at UTK.

I have personally experienced  racism, ethnocentrism and sexism (a surprising amount is overt, a lot of it is subtle and much is structural in nature) and I have experienced the place as having a highly intolerant climate. In my opinion, there is denial about the climate by central administration who, from my perspective, is given to issuing lofty platitudes publicly, while enabling and supporting bad behavior and bad managers privately.

I have experienced and observe a lot of conniving, back-biting, favoritism, nepotism, cronyism, unfairness, pettiness, lying and deceitful behavior. I am surprised at how much of this behavior there is.

In my opinion, the city of Knoxville, where UTK is located, contributes to its culture of intolerance and bigotry. Knoxville is not a good place to live as far as I am concerned - it is very "old South" (and not in the charming way).  I don't feel safe here.  

In Tennessee, where UTK is located, there is no tax on wages, but sales tax is very high and even food is taxed  which results in a regressive tax structure in the state - it is more expensive than it seems to live in Knoxville, especially if you don't make much money.  Many salaries at UTK are low. If you are considering moving to UTK, be careful about the kind of counsel that you receive when it comes to the actual cost of living. Don't be deceived by the line, "but there's no state tax to worry about!" -especially if you get offered what you think is a low salary.

In my  opinion, staff are not treated as well as they should be and I have witnessed staff (and even faculty) being constantly bullied and oppressed by other faculty and administrators; there is a lot of quiet desperation and people will tell you terrible stories about their experiences (off the record) if you get to know them and they trust you. People are afraid to speak up when wrongs happen.  Most people seem to look the other way when something bad happens or quietly be happy that it didn't happen to them (this time...)

I don't see that central administration is concerned with the issues confronting regular people in the state even though it is a land grant university. Central administration appears obsessed with rising in national rankings, but not with activities that help people in the state enhance or improve their lives. In my opinion, central administration panders to the state legislature without offering real suggestions as to how higher education can improve everyone's quality of life. UTK is not unique in this, but TN is not a wealthy enough state to waste resources on chasing rankings that only serve to improve senior administrator pay.
